milestones.title: Lifts head during tummy time
milestones.description: Baby briefly lifts their head while lying on their stomach.
milestones.tips: Offer short sessions of tummy time multiple times a day starting at birth.

milestones.title: Pushes up on arms when on tummy
milestones.description: Baby pushes up onto their forearms while on their belly.
milestones.tips: Continue daily tummy time to help your baby strengthen neck and arm muscles.

milestones.title: Rolls from tummy to back
milestones.description: Baby learns to roll from their stomach to their back.
milestones.tips: Encourage rolling by gently guiding baby’s legs and cheering when they try.

milestones.title: Rolls from back to tummy
milestones.description: Baby rolls from their back onto their tummy.
milestones.tips: Place toys to the side of baby to motivate rolling over during play.

milestones.title: Sits without support
milestones.description: Baby can sit up steadily without needing support.
milestones.tips: Sit on the floor with baby between your legs to practice sitting up safely.

milestones.title: Stands with support
milestones.description: Baby can support their weight on their legs when held or supported.
milestones.tips: Let baby bounce on your lap or stand while holding onto furniture (under supervision).

milestones.title: Crawls on hands and knees
milestones.description: Baby moves forward on hands and knees (crawling).
milestones.tips: Create a safe, open play area with toys placed just out of reach to encourage crawling.

milestones.title: Pulls to stand
milestones.description: Baby pulls themselves up to stand while holding onto furniture or your hands.
milestones.tips: Place sturdy furniture or activity tables within baby’s reach to encourage pulling up.

milestones.title: Cruises along furniture
milestones.description: Baby walks sideways while holding onto furniture for support.
milestones.tips: Encourage cruising by arranging furniture so baby can step between pieces safely.

milestones.title: Stands alone briefly
milestones.description: Baby can stand without support for a few seconds.
milestones.tips: Offer plenty of floor time and let baby practice standing barefoot on a safe surface.

milestones.title: Takes first independent steps
milestones.description: Baby takes their first steps without help, beginning to walk independently.
milestones.tips: Stand or kneel a few steps away and encourage baby to walk into your arms.

milestones.title: Walks independently
milestones.description: Toddler walks on their own with a steady gait, seldom falling.
milestones.tips: Provide a safe, open environment for walking and soft shoes or bare feet for better grip.

milestones.title: Runs short distance
milestones.description: Child begins to run with coordination (faster than a walk, but may still fall occasionally).
milestones.tips: Play chase or outdoor games to help your toddler practice running in a safe area.

milestones.title: Kicks a ball
milestones.description: Child can kick a light ball forward by swinging their foot.
milestones.tips: Use a soft ball and demonstrate kicking; cheer when your child tries to kick the ball.

milestones.title: Jumps with both feet off ground
milestones.description: Child can jump up, briefly getting both feet off the ground.
milestones.tips: Hold your child’s hands and practice jumping together, or use a low step to jump off.

milestones.title: Holds a toy briefly
milestones.description: Baby briefly grasps a rattle or toy when placed in hand.
milestones.tips: Place soft toys in baby's hand and gently encourage grasping.

milestones.title: Reaches for dangling objects
milestones.description: Baby reaches out to grab or bat at toys or objects above them.
milestones.tips: Hang a colorful toy within reach during playtime to motivate your baby to reach and swipe.

milestones.title: Transfers toy from hand to hand
milestones.description: Baby moves an object from one hand to the other while playing.
milestones.tips: Offer toys and let baby pass them between hands to develop coordination.

milestones.title: Uses raking grasp
milestones.description: Baby uses all fingers to rake small objects toward themselves.
milestones.tips: Provide safe finger foods (like puffs) on a tray for baby to practice picking them up.

milestones.title: Picks up small objects with pincer grasp
milestones.description: Baby uses thumb and index finger to pick up tiny items like cereal pieces.
milestones.tips: Place small soft finger foods on baby's high-chair tray to encourage pincer grasp.

milestones.title: Bangs objects together
milestones.description: Baby bangs two toys or objects together to hear the sound.
milestones.tips: Give your baby two blocks or lids and show them how to tap them together.

milestones.title: Puts objects into a container
milestones.description: Baby can release items into a container or bucket.
milestones.tips: Use a soft container and demonstrate dropping blocks in and dumping them out for your baby.

milestones.title: Claps hands
milestones.description: Baby brings both hands together to clap.
milestones.tips: Play clapping games like “Pat-a-cake” to help your baby practice clapping.

milestones.title: Scribbles on paper
milestones.description: Toddler makes marks on paper by scribbling with crayon or pencil.
milestones.tips: Provide large crayons or markers and paper, and encourage your child’s early drawing without worrying about the mess.

milestones.title: Stacks two blocks
milestones.description: Toddler balances two blocks on top of each other.
milestones.tips: Offer a variety of blocks and cheer when your toddler successfully stacks them, even if the tower is small.

milestones.title: Turns pages of a book
milestones.description: Child can turn pages in a board book, often turning multiple pages at once.
milestones.tips: Read board books together and let your child help turn the pages at their own pace.

milestones.title: Stacks five or more blocks
milestones.description: Child builds a tower of five or more blocks independently.
milestones.tips: Challenge your child to build a taller block tower and celebrate their success, even if it topples.

milestones.title: Uses child-safe scissors to snip paper
milestones.description: Child begins to use scissors to make small cuts in paper (with supervision).
milestones.tips: Provide child-safe scissors and paper for your child to practice cutting simple lines or snips (always with supervision).

milestones.title: Copies a circle or line
milestones.description: Child can imitate drawing a simple line or circle when shown.
milestones.tips: Draw simple shapes and encourage your child to copy them with a thick crayon.

milestones.title: Draws a person with 2+ body parts
milestones.description: Child draws a person with at least two body parts (such as a head and one other feature).
milestones.tips: Encourage drawing by asking your child to draw your family; don't worry about accuracy—praise their effort.

milestones.title: Coos and makes vowel sounds
milestones.description: Baby begins to make cooing sounds and simple vowel noises.
milestones.tips: Respond to your baby's sounds with conversation and smiles.

milestones.title: Laughs out loud
milestones.description: Baby laughs or giggles in response to playful interaction.
milestones.tips: Play gentle tickling games or make funny faces to encourage your baby to laugh.

milestones.title: Babbles with consonant sounds
milestones.description: Baby makes repeated consonant-vowel sounds like “bababa” or “dadada.”
milestones.tips: Babble back to your baby and use simple sounds; show excitement when they try new sounds.

milestones.title: Responds to own name
milestones.description: Baby turns to look when you say their name.
milestones.tips: Use your baby's name often in songs and conversation to help them recognize it.

milestones.title: Says “mama” or “dada” (nonspecific)
milestones.description: Baby says “mama” or “dada” sounds, but not necessarily to the correct parent yet.
milestones.tips: Encourage babbling by talking with baby and labeling yourself as “mama” or “dada” in third person.

milestones.title: Waves goodbye or uses simple gestures
milestones.description: Baby uses gestures like waving or shaking head “no” to communicate.
milestones.tips: Model simple gestures (waving, nodding) and use them consistently with words (like “bye-bye”) so baby learns both.

milestones.title: Says one word besides “mama”/“dada”
milestones.description: Baby says at least one meaningful word other than names (for example, “hi” or “ball”).
milestones.tips: Name familiar people and objects frequently; celebrate when your baby tries to say a new word, even if it's not clear.

milestones.title: Points to show what they want
milestones.description: Baby points at objects or people to draw attention or express a want.
milestones.tips: When your baby points, label the object (“You see the cat!”) to reinforce that communication.

milestones.title: Uses 5–10 words
milestones.description: Toddler says around five to ten words regularly, though pronunciation may not be perfect.
milestones.tips: Keep talking with your toddler, and repeat words back correctly; read books to introduce new simple words.

milestones.title: Identifies body parts when asked
milestones.description: Toddler can point to a couple of body parts (like nose, tummy) when you name them.
milestones.tips: Make a game of naming body parts during dressing or bath time ("Where is your nose?").

milestones.title: Combines two words
milestones.description: Toddler starts using two-word phrases like “more milk” or “Daddy go.”
milestones.tips: When your child uses one word, expand it (if they say “ball,” you say “big ball”); encourage them to repeat the phrase.

milestones.title: Half of speech understood by caregiver
milestones.description: About half of your toddler’s speech is understandable to familiar listeners.
milestones.tips: Listen patiently and encourage your child to talk; avoid correcting pronunciation harshly—model the correct words gently.

milestones.title: Uses 2–3 word sentences
milestones.description: Toddler speaks in short phrases or sentences of two to three words (e.g., “Mommy go home”).
milestones.tips: Have simple back-and-forth conversations; ask questions that prompt short answers to practice new phrases.

milestones.title: Knows 50 or more words
milestones.description: Toddler’s vocabulary expands to at least 50 words by around two years of age.
milestones.tips: Keep reading and talking together. Introduce new words during daily activities, pointing out and naming new things.

milestones.title: Tells simple story or idea (4+ word sentences)
milestones.description: Child speaks in longer sentences (four or more words) and can tell you about something that happened or a make-believe story.
milestones.tips: Ask your child about their day or to imagine a story; listen patiently and ask questions to encourage them to continue talking.

milestones.title: Recognizes familiar people
milestones.description: Baby shows recognition of familiar faces and may react differently to strangers.
milestones.tips: Maintain consistent routines and introduce new faces gradually.

milestones.title: Searches for partially hidden object
milestones.description: Baby looks for an object that is partially hidden (e.g., peeks under a blanket for a toy).
milestones.tips: Play partial hide-and-seek games with toys, like covering a toy halfway and encouraging baby to find it.

milestones.title: Searches for fully hidden object
milestones.description: Baby finds a toy completely hidden under a cup or blanket, demonstrating object permanence.
milestones.tips: Play peek-a-boo or hide toys under cloths for your baby to uncover, building their understanding that objects still exist when unseen.

milestones.title: Uses simple strategy to get toy
milestones.description: Baby figures out simple ways to retrieve an out-of-reach toy (for example, pulling a cloth to bring a toy closer).
milestones.tips: Place a favorite toy just out of reach but on a small blanket, and let your baby discover how to pull the blanket (help a little if needed).

milestones.title: Imitates gestures or actions
milestones.description: Baby copies simple actions they see others do (like clapping or waving after you do).
milestones.tips: Demonstrate fun actions (clapping hands, blowing kisses) and praise your baby when they attempt to imitate you.

milestones.title: Follows simple one-step instruction
milestones.description: Toddler can follow a simple one-step direction, especially if given with a gesture (e.g., “Give me the ball”).
milestones.tips: Start with easy requests during play ("Roll me the ball") and help them complete the action, giving praise when they do.

milestones.title: Uses objects correctly (e.g., cup, brush)
milestones.description: Toddler shows understanding of what common objects are for (for example, pretends to brush hair or drink from a cup).
milestones.tips: Give your child everyday safe objects (spoon, cup, brush) during play and show them how each is used, letting them imitate.

milestones.title: Engages in simple pretend play
milestones.description: Toddler uses toys or objects in pretend play (like feeding a doll or talking on a toy phone).
milestones.tips: Play pretend with your child—have a tea party with dolls or use a toy phone to ‘talk,’ encouraging their imagination.

milestones.title: Matches shapes or colors
milestones.description: Toddler can sort or match objects by shape or color (for example, putting circles in a circle hole of a shape sorter).
milestones.tips: Play sorting games with blocks or household items by color or shape; praise attempts even if they aren't perfect.

milestones.title: Completes a simple puzzle
milestones.description: Child can solve a simple puzzle (like a three-piece form board or basic inset puzzle).
milestones.tips: Provide simple puzzles with large pieces and guide your child in finding where pieces go. Encourage them and give hints as needed.

milestones.title: Understands “mine” and “yours”
milestones.description: Child understands the concept of possession, distinguishing “mine” versus “yours.”
milestones.tips: Use words like “mine” and “yours” in context ("This is your coat, that is Mommy’s coat") to reinforce the idea of ownership.

milestones.title: Understands simple time concepts
milestones.description: Child starts to understand basic time concepts like “later” or routines like morning vs. night.
milestones.tips: Talk about your daily routine in order ("After dinner we take a bath, then bedtime") to help your child learn sequences of events.

milestones.title: Understands basic opposites
milestones.description: Child knows common opposites like up/down, big/small and can sort or choose items based on those concepts.
milestones.tips: Use everyday opportunities to talk about opposites ("This cup is full, that one is empty") and let your child find or demonstrate the opposite.

milestones.title: Counts to 10
milestones.description: Child can count out loud up to ten (though they might skip a number or two).
milestones.tips: Count toys, snacks, or steps together. Make counting part of playtime ("How many blocks do you have?").

milestones.title: Remembers parts of a story
milestones.description: Child can recall and share some details from a familiar story or event.
milestones.tips: After reading a story or going on an outing, ask your child to tell you what happened in their own words.

milestones.title: Smiles spontaneously
milestones.description: Baby begins to smile at people without needing to be stimulated.
milestones.tips: Engage in face-to-face interaction and mirror your baby's expressions.

milestones.title: Smiles responsively at others
milestones.description: Baby smiles back when someone smiles or talks to them (a social smile).
milestones.tips: Smile often at your baby and talk gently; this encourages them to connect and smile back.

milestones.title: Shows excitement with familiar people
milestones.description: Baby clearly shows excitement (smiles, waves arms) when seeing a familiar caregiver.
milestones.tips: Respond to your baby’s excitement with warm attention and say the names of familiar people when they appear ("Here comes Grandma!").

milestones.title: Shows stranger anxiety
milestones.description: Baby may be cautious or fearful around unfamiliar people, clinging to caregivers.
milestones.tips: Introduce new people gradually and stay near; let your baby warm up at their own pace to strangers.

milestones.title: Plays peek-a-boo
milestones.description: Baby participates in simple social games like peek-a-boo, indicating anticipation and joy.
milestones.tips: Play peek-a-boo often; pause to let your baby respond or initiate the game, building their social engagement.

milestones.title: Has a favorite toy or blanket
milestones.description: Baby develops an attachment to a special comfort object (like a blanket or stuffed animal).
milestones.tips: Allow your baby to have their comfort item during naps or stressful times for reassurance; it’s a normal part of self-soothing.

milestones.title: Experiences separation anxiety
milestones.description: Toddler may become upset when a parent leaves, showing separation anxiety.
milestones.tips: Keep goodbyes short and calm. Establish a goodbye routine and reassure your child that you’ll be back.

milestones.title: Imitates others during play
milestones.description: Toddler copies behaviors they see (like pretending to talk on phone after seeing an adult do it).
milestones.tips: Be a good role model; do fun, simple actions (like hugging a doll) and praise your child when they imitate your kind behaviors.

milestones.title: Shows defiant behavior (says “no” often)
milestones.description: Toddler may say “no” often or test limits as they start to assert independence.
milestones.tips: Stay calm and consistent with rules. Offer choices when possible ("blue shirt or red shirt?") to give your toddler a sense of control.

milestones.title: Plays alongside other children (parallel play)
milestones.description: Child plays next to other children but not yet actively with them (parallel play).
milestones.tips: Provide opportunities for playdates or playgroups; even if kids play separately, they learn from being near each other.

milestones.title: Shows empathy (tries to comfort others)
milestones.description: Child may attempt to comfort a crying peer or adult, showing early empathy.
milestones.tips: Label emotions ("Your friend is sad") and encourage gentle actions like patting or offering a toy when someone is upset.

milestones.title: Takes turns with help (simple social rules)
milestones.description: Child starts to take turns and share with others when reminded, showing understanding of simple social rules.
milestones.tips: Practice turn-taking games (rolling a ball back and forth, or sharing crayons) and praise your child for waiting their turn.

milestones.title: Engages in imaginative group play
milestones.description: Child engages in imaginative play with others, possibly including pretend friends or scenarios.
milestones.tips: Join your child's pretend games and let them take the lead; ask questions about their imaginary stories to show interest.

milestones.title: Plays cooperatively with peers
milestones.description: Child plays with other children with a common goal or theme, cooperating in group play.
milestones.tips: Organize simple group activities (building something together or pretending together) to encourage teamwork and sharing.

milestones.title: Separates easily from parents (in familiar settings)
milestones.description: Child is comfortable parting from parents at daycare or school, without undue distress.
milestones.tips: Establish a consistent goodbye routine; encourage your child's independence by reassuring them you will return after school or daycare.

milestones.title: Brings hands to mouth
milestones.description: Baby starts to bring hands to mouth consistently.
milestones.tips: Keep baby's hands clean and provide safe teething toys when needed.

milestones.title: Opens mouth for spoon (starting solids)
milestones.description: Baby opens their mouth when a spoon with food approaches, ready to eat solids.
milestones.tips: Introduce solid foods slowly at around 6 months; look for baby’s cues of readiness, like opening mouth or leaning forward.

milestones.title: Holds bottle independently
milestones.description: Baby can hold their own bottle during feeding (for at least a short time).
milestones.tips: When bottle-feeding, allow baby to place hands on the bottle; use bottles they can grip easily.

milestones.title: Starts finger-feeding
milestones.description: Baby picks up small pieces of food and feeds themselves using their fingers.
milestones.tips: Offer soft finger foods (banana slices, puffs) that baby can safely pick up and chew.

milestones.title: Drinks from open cup with help
milestones.description: Baby can drink from a cup held by an adult, or hold a small cup with help (some spilling).
milestones.tips: Practice with a small plastic cup and a little water; support the cup with your hands while they try drinking.

milestones.title: Uses a sippy cup independently
milestones.description: Toddler drinks from a sippy cup or straw cup without assistance.
milestones.tips: Transition from bottle to sippy or straw cup around 12 months; demonstrate and let them practice with water to minimize mess.

milestones.title: Attempts to use spoon or fork
milestones.description: Toddler tries to feed themselves with a spoon or fork, though they might spill.
milestones.tips: Give your toddler a child-safe spoon or fork at meals; expect mess and praise their efforts to self-feed.

milestones.title: Helps with dressing (pushes arm through sleeve)
milestones.description: Toddler cooperates with dressing by extending arm or leg into clothing.
milestones.tips: Make dressing fun—encourage your child to push their arm through a sleeve or step into pants by themselves.

milestones.title: Removes hat, socks, or shoes
milestones.description: Toddler can take off simple clothing items such as hat, socks, or loose shoes.
milestones.tips: Encourage your child’s efforts to undress by giving praise. Loose-fitting clothes are easier for practice.

milestones.title: Shows potty training readiness
milestones.description: Toddler shows signs of readiness for toilet training (stays dry for a couple hours, shows awareness of a dirty diaper).
milestones.tips: Look for readiness signs like dry periods or interest in the bathroom; introduce a potty chair casually and encourage practice.

milestones.title: Washes hands with help
milestones.description: Toddler can wash their hands at a sink with some help (needs assistance with soap and thorough rinsing).
milestones.tips: Teach handwashing as a fun routine; guide your child's hands under the water and help them use soap while singing a short song.

milestones.title: Uses spoon with little spilling
milestones.description: Toddler feeds themselves well with a spoon, with only occasional spills.
milestones.tips: Provide child-sized utensils and plenty of practice. Thicker foods (like yogurt or oatmeal) are easier for toddlers to scoop.

milestones.title: Puts on simple clothing with help
milestones.description: Child can put on some clothing (like a hat, shoes, or pants) with a bit of assistance.
milestones.tips: Lay out clothing and let your child try to dress. Offer help only as needed, and choose easy clothing (loose pants, slip-on shoes).

milestones.title: Daytime toilet trained
milestones.description: Child stays dry during the day and uses the potty with few accidents.
milestones.tips: Maintain a consistent potty routine and celebrate successes. Expect occasional accidents and stay patient.

milestones.title: Brushes teeth with supervision
milestones.description: Child can brush their teeth with some supervision (parents may need to finish up for thorough cleaning).
milestones.tips: Let your child practice brushing their teeth first, then you take a turn. Use a small toothbrush and a pea-sized amount of toothpaste.

milestones.title: Turns head toward sounds
milestones.description: Baby begins to turn head toward familiar sounds and voices.
milestones.tips: Talk to your baby often and introduce gentle, varied sounds.

milestones.title: Startles at loud noises
milestones.description: Newborn blinks or jumps at sudden, loud sounds.
milestones.tips: Notice your baby's reactions to noise. Protect them from very loud sounds, but normal household noise is okay.

milestones.title: Calms with gentle rocking or soft sounds
milestones.description: Baby can be soothed by gentle motion, soft singing, or white noise when fussy.
milestones.tips: Rock your baby, sing lullabies, or use calming sounds (like a fan) to help soothe them when they’re upset.

milestones.title: Visually tracks moving objects
milestones.description: Baby follows a moving object or person with their eyes from side to side.
milestones.tips: Slowly move a colorful toy in front of your baby and encourage them to follow it with their eyes.

milestones.title: Enjoys various movements (bouncing, swinging)
milestones.description: Baby shows pleasure in different movements (being gently bounced, rocked, or lifted in the air).
milestones.tips: Try different gentle motions (swinging in your arms, infant swing, bouncing on your knee) to see what movements your baby enjoys.

milestones.title: Explores objects with mouth and hands
milestones.description: Baby mouths toys and feels them with hands to learn about their texture and shape.
milestones.tips: Offer clean, baby-safe objects of various textures for your baby to touch and chew on under supervision.

milestones.title: Not upset by everyday noises
milestones.description: Baby is generally not bothered by common sounds like the vacuum cleaner, phone ringing, or doorbell.
milestones.tips: Expose your baby to typical household noises at a moderate level; reassure them with a calm voice if they seem unsure.

milestones.title: Investigates toys with different textures
milestones.description: Baby explores toys of various textures (smooth, soft, bumpy) using both hands and mouth.
milestones.tips: Provide toys with safe different textures (cloth, rubber, plastic) to encourage sensory exploration.

milestones.title: Enjoys listening to songs or music
milestones.description: Toddler shows pleasure when hearing favorite songs or music, sometimes dancing or swaying.
milestones.tips: Play a variety of music and sing with your toddler. Encourage them to dance or clap along to engage multiple senses.

milestones.title: Shows preferences for certain foods/textures
milestones.description: Toddler may prefer certain food textures or flavors and make faces or refuse others.
milestones.tips: Offer a variety of foods with different textures and flavors; respect dislikes but keep reintroducing occasionally in a positive way.

milestones.title: Observes environment from different positions
milestones.description: Baby looks around and remains curious in various positions (lying on back or tummy, sitting, crawling).
milestones.tips: Give baby safe space to move between positions (floor playtime) so they can explore how things look from each new vantage point.

milestones.title: Flips switches or pushes buttons (cause and effect)
milestones.description: Toddler likes to flip light switches or push buttons repeatedly to see the effect (lights turning on/off, toy sounds).
milestones.tips: Provide toys with buttons or cause-and-effect activities. Allow your child to safely toggle a light switch while describing the action ("lights on/off").

milestones.title: Enjoys messy play with different textures
milestones.description: Child willingly touches messy substances (sand, finger paint) during play, showing comfort with different textures.
milestones.tips: Encourage sensory play with materials like playdough, shaving cream, or mud. Let your child get messy and praise their creativity.

milestones.title: Adjusts to loud sounds without distress
milestones.description: Child tolerates moderately loud noises (vacuum, blender) without significant fear, possibly covering ears but not panicking.
milestones.tips: Prepare your child for loud noises ("I’m going to vacuum now") and make it a game to dance or sing along with the noise to make it less scary.
